elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">A novel 4d–4f coordination polymer [EuAg(imdc)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) (imdc<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>imidazoledicarboxylate) has been hydrothermally synthesized. X-ray single-crystal structural analyses reveal that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is three-dimensional framework constructed from one-dimensional chain. <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> also displayed photoluminescent properties in the red range at room temperature.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

A novel 4d-4f coordination polymer [EuAg(imdc)2] n  (1) (imdc=imidazoledicarboxylate) has been hydrothermally synthesized. X-ray single-crystal structural analyses reveal that 1 is three-dimensional framework constructed from one-dimensional chain. 1 also displayed photoluminescent properties in the red range at room temperature.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">A novel 4d–4f heterometallic coordination polymer [EuAg(imdc)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) (imdc<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>imidazoledicarboxylate) has been hydrothermally synthesized and characterized by elemental analysis, IR, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. X-ray single-crystal structural analysis reveals that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is a three-dimensional framework. Furthermore, <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> also displayed photoluminescent properties in the red range at room temperature.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A novel 4d-4f heterometallic coordination polymer [EuAg(imdc)2] n  (1) (imdc=imidazoledicarboxylate) has been hydrothermally synthesized and characterized by elemental analysis, IR, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. X-ray single-crystal structural analysis reveals that 1 is a three-dimensional framework. Furthermore, 1 also displayed photoluminescent properties in the red range at room temperature.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">In recent years, the assembly of three-dimensional heterometallic metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) based on the principle of crystal engineering is of great interest . The rapid development in this field is not only because of the heterometallic MOFs intriguing architectures and topologies , but also due to the possibility to develop more advanced materials, such as, e.g. catalysts , luminescent probes , magnetic materials  and materials useful for gas adsorption . However the development of those materials is difficult owing to complicated competing coordinations of transition metals and rare earth metals with the same ligands. Very often those competing reactions often generate preferably homometallic MOFs instead of heterometallic structures . So, suitable ligands containing appropriate coordination sites and suitable <ce:italic>d</ce:italic>-block or <ce:italic>f-</ce:italic>block metal ions should be selected to assemble heterometallic structures under different reaction conditions . The <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-heterocyclic carboxylic acid is good candidate for assembling such heterometallic MOFs due to the existence of <ce:italic>N</ce:italic> and <ce:italic>O</ce:italic> mixed-donor atoms in the ligand . Zhao et al. reported a series of Zeolite-type 3d–4f heterometallic MOFs with a 3D nanotubular structure based on pyridine-2,6-carboxylate . Prasad et al. reported a cubic Gd–Mn 3D MOF structure with a ferromagnetic interaction . With respect to 4d–4f MOFs, it is noteworthy that previous investigations have the following features: these studies have been almost exclusively devoted to isonicotinic ligands, and little or no attention has been paid to other carboxylate ligands .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In recent years, the assembly of three-dimensional heterometallic metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) based on the principle of crystal engineering is of great interest . The rapid development in this field is not only because of the heterometallic MOFs intriguing architectures and topologies , but also due to the possibility to develop more advanced materials, such as, e.g. catalysts , luminescent probes , magnetic materials  and materials useful for gas adsorption . However the development of those materials is difficult owing to complicated competing coordinations of transition metals and rare earth metals with the same ligands. Very often those competing reactions often generate preferably homometallic MOFs instead of heterometallic structures . So, suitable ligands containing appropriate coordination sites and suitable d-block or f-block metal ions should be selected to assemble heterometallic structures under different reaction conditions . The N-heterocyclic carboxylic acid is good candidate for assembling such heterometallic MOFs due to the existence of N and O mixed-donor atoms in the ligand . Zhao et al. reported a series of Zeolite-type 3d-4f heterometallic MOFs with a 3D nanotubular structure based on pyridine-2,6-carboxylate . Prasad et al. reported a cubic Gd-Mn 3D MOF structure with a ferromagnetic interaction . With respect to 4d-4f MOFs, it is noteworthy that previous investigations have the following features: these studies have been almost exclusively devoted to isonicotinic ligands, and little or no attention has been paid to other carboxylate ligands .

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">In this study we chose for 4,5-imidazoledicarboxylic acid (imdc) as multifunctional ligand in our experiment for the following reasons: (1) The 4,5-imidazoledicarboxylic acid as a multifunctional ligand, may be completely or partially deprotonated and has been proven to be able to form novel structures with single transition metals or Ln ions . (2) The adjacent two carboxylate groups of 4,5-imidazoledicarboxylate could coordinate to lanthanide ions and the two nitrogen atoms of the imidazole ring could connect simultaneously 4d metal ions in appropriate reaction conditions. In addition, we used hydrothermal reaction conditions to enhance metal–ligand interactions rather than metal–water coordination. In this way we avoid quenching of the luminescence intensity . In this study, we report on a novel three-dimensional 4d–4f heterometallic metal-organic coordination polymer: [EuAg(imdc)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>). The solid-state photoluminescent properties of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> indicate that this compound may be a candidate for potential photoluminescent material.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In this study we chose for 4,5-imidazoledicarboxylic acid (imdc) as multifunctional ligand in our experiment for the following reasons: (1) The 4,5-imidazoledicarboxylic acid as a multifunctional ligand, may be completely or partially deprotonated and has been proven to be able to form novel structures with single transition metals or Ln ions . (2) The adjacent two carboxylate groups of 4,5-imidazoledicarboxylate could coordinate to lanthanide ions and the two nitrogen atoms of the imidazole ring could connect simultaneously 4d metal ions in appropriate reaction conditions. In addition, we used hydrothermal reaction conditions to enhance metal-ligand interactions rather than metal-water coordination. In this way we avoid quenching of the luminescence intensity . In this study, we report on a novel three-dimensional 4d-4f heterometallic metal-organic coordination polymer: [EuAg(imdc)2] n  (1). The solid-state photoluminescent properties of 1 indicate that this compound may be a candidate for potential photoluminescent material.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">All chemicals were of reagent grade quality obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. A mixture of Eu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (0.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 0.568<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g), Ag(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>) (0.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 0.0510<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g), 4,5-imidazoledicarboxylic acid (0.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 0.357<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g) and water (12<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) was stirred for 30<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min in air. Thereafter, the mixture was transferred to a 23<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL Teflon reactor and kept at 180<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 3 days under autogenous pressure. Cooling the reactor subsequently to room temperature at a rate of 10.8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C/h colorless crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were obtained. Finally, the colorless crystals were washed with deionized water and absolute ethanol (yield: 45% based on Eu). IR: 3441(w), 1554(s), 1508(s), 1465(s), 1383(s), 1244(m), 1100(m), 818(s), 782(s). Anal. Calcd. for C<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf> EuAg(%), C, 21.15; H, 0.71; N, 9.86. Found (%): C, 21.13; H, 0.71; N, 9.89.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: All chemicals were of reagent grade quality obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. A mixture of Eu2O3 (0.3mmol, 0.568g), Ag(NO3) (0.3mmol, 0.0510g), 4,5-imidazoledicarboxylic acid (0.3mmol, 0.357g) and water (12mL) was stirred for 30min in air. Thereafter, the mixture was transferred to a 23mL Teflon reactor and kept at 180°C for 3 days under autogenous pressure. Cooling the reactor subsequently to room temperature at a rate of 10.8°C/h colorless crystals of 1 were obtained. Finally, the colorless crystals were washed with deionized water and absolute ethanol (yield: 45% based on Eu). IR: 3441(w), 1554(s), 1508(s), 1465(s), 1383(s), 1244(m), 1100(m), 818(s), 782(s). Anal. Calcd. for C10H4N4O8 EuAg(%), C, 21.15; H, 0.71; N, 9.86. Found (%): C, 21.13; H, 0.71; N, 9.89.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The single-crystal X-ray analysis  reveals that the fundamental unit of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> consists of one Eu(III), one Ag(I) and two imdc ligands, as shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig1"></ce:float-anchor>. Each Eu(III) is coordinated to eight oxygen atoms from five different imdc ligands, and exhibits a distorted dodecahedral configuration. This is a very rare example in which five multifunctional ligands coordinating to one metal center . Compared with earlier reported work, the distances of EuO fall in the normal range . The imdc ligands adopt a <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-mode to coordinated with Eu(III) ions, two oxygen atoms of the adjacent carboxylate group chelates with one Eu(III), while the remaining oxygen atoms of the carboxylate group links to two different Eu(III) respectively, as shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig6"></ce:float-anchor>. Although the imdc ligand has more than nine coordination modes , the mode in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is unique for the imdc ligand. As far as Ag(I) is concerned, it exhibits a linear geometry, being coordinated to two nitrogen atoms from two different imdc ligands [Ag1–N1, 2.113(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å; Ag1–N2, 2.113(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å; N1–Ag1–N1, 169.59°(16)]. The Eu(III) ions and Ag(I) ions were bridged by imdc ligands and arranged in an alternating manner to form a chain (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig2"></ce:float-anchor>). Furthermore, the chains are linked by imdc to construct a two-dimensional network (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig3"></ce:float-anchor>). It is interesting that every two Eu(III) ions are surrounded by eight Ag(I) ions in its vicinity, while every two Ag(I) ions have eight Eu(III) ions as nearest neighbors, which confirms the Eu–Ag(1:1) molar ratio. The two-dimensional networks are connected further to each other by the O–C–O of the carboxyl group of imdc generating a three-dimensional framework. Further insight into the structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> can be gained by reducing the three-dimensional structure to simple rod geometries, as shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig4"></ce:float-anchor>. The framework contains a 4f layer and a 4d layer. All the Eu(III) in the 4f layer are perfectly coplanar and the same holds for all Ag(I) in the 4d layer. In this way an alternating arrangement is possible resulting in a cubical-like architecture.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The single-crystal X-ray analysis  reveals that the fundamental unit of 1 consists of one Eu(III), one Ag(I) and two imdc ligands, as shown in  . Each Eu(III) is coordinated to eight oxygen atoms from five different imdc ligands, and exhibits a distorted dodecahedral configuration. This is a very rare example in which five multifunctional ligands coordinating to one metal center . Compared with earlier reported work, the distances of EuO fall in the normal range . The imdc ligands adopt a μ 3-mode to coordinated with Eu(III) ions, two oxygen atoms of the adjacent carboxylate group chelates with one Eu(III), while the remaining oxygen atoms of the carboxylate group links to two different Eu(III) respectively, as shown in  . Although the imdc ligand has more than nine coordination modes , the mode in 1 is unique for the imdc ligand. As far as Ag(I) is concerned, it exhibits a linear geometry, being coordinated to two nitrogen atoms from two different imdc ligands [Ag1-N1, 2.113(3)Å; Ag1-N2, 2.113(3)Å; N1-Ag1-N1, 169.59°(16)]. The Eu(III) ions and Ag(I) ions were bridged by imdc ligands and arranged in an alternating manner to form a chain ( ). Furthermore, the chains are linked by imdc to construct a two-dimensional network ( ). It is interesting that every two Eu(III) ions are surrounded by eight Ag(I) ions in its vicinity, while every two Ag(I) ions have eight Eu(III) ions as nearest neighbors, which confirms the Eu-Ag(1:1) molar ratio. The two-dimensional networks are connected further to each other by the O-C-O of the carboxyl group of imdc generating a three-dimensional framework. Further insight into the structure of 1 can be gained by reducing the three-dimensional structure to simple rod geometries, as shown in  . The framework contains a 4f layer and a 4d layer. All the Eu(III) in the 4f layer are perfectly coplanar and the same holds for all Ag(I) in the 4d layer. In this way an alternating arrangement is possible resulting in a cubical-like architecture.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Taking into account the excellent luminescent properties of Eu<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ion, the luminescences of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was investigated at room temperature. Excitation of solid <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> at 394<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm reveals that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> displays intense red luminescence (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig5"></ce:float-anchor>) and exhibits the characteristic transition of a Eu<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ion. The transitions are attributed to <ce:sup loc="pre">5</ce:sup>D<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:sup loc="pre">7</ce:sup>F<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">J</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:italic>J</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0, 1, 2, 3, 4) transition, i.e. the weak intensities of emission at 537<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm and 653<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm are respectively <ce:sup loc="pre">5</ce:sup>D<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:sup loc="pre">7</ce:sup>F<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf> and <ce:sup loc="pre">5</ce:sup>D<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:sup loc="pre">7</ce:sup>F<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> transition. It is well know that <ce:sup loc="pre">5</ce:sup>D<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:sup loc="pre">7</ce:sup>F<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf> transition is strictly forbidden in a field of symmetry and, therefore, the Eu(III) in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> should occupy sites with a low symmetry. These results are in excellent agreement with the crystal structure analysis. The <ce:sup loc="pre">5</ce:sup>D<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:sup loc="pre">7</ce:sup>F<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> transition at 592<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm and <ce:sup loc="pre">5</ce:sup>D<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:sup loc="pre">7</ce:sup>F<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> transition at 702<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm corresponds to a magnetic dipole transition both with medium–strong intensities. The most intensive emission in the luminescent spectra is the <ce:sup loc="pre">5</ce:sup>D<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:sup loc="pre">7</ce:sup>F<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> transition at 612<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, which is the so-called hypersensitive transition responsible for the brilliant-red emission of this complex .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Taking into account the excellent luminescent properties of Eu3+ ion, the luminescences of 1 was investigated at room temperature. Excitation of solid 1 at 394nm reveals that 1 displays intense red luminescence ( ) and exhibits the characteristic transition of a Eu3+ ion. The transitions are attributed to 5D0 → 7F J  (J =0, 1, 2, 3, 4) transition, i.e. the weak intensities of emission at 537nm and 653nm are respectively 5D0 → 7F0 and 5D0 → 7F3 transition. It is well know that 5D0 → 7F0 transition is strictly forbidden in a field of symmetry and, therefore, the Eu(III) in 1 should occupy sites with a low symmetry. These results are in excellent agreement with the crystal structure analysis. The 5D0 → 7F1 transition at 592nm and 5D0 → 7F4 transition at 702nm corresponds to a magnetic dipole transition both with medium-strong intensities. The most intensive emission in the luminescent spectra is the 5D0 → 7F2 transition at 612nm, which is the so-called hypersensitive transition responsible for the brilliant-red emission of this complex .

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">In summary, we have synthesized and structurally characterized a 3D heterometallic coordination polymer [EuAg(imdc)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> by using hydrothermal methods. Eu(III) and Ag(I) in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> are bridged by 4,5-imidazoledicarboxylate and arranged in an alternating fashion to construct a cubical-like architecture. The solid-state photoluminescent properties of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> indicate that the new compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> may be a candidate for potential photoactive materials.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In summary, we have synthesized and structurally characterized a 3D heterometallic coordination polymer [EuAg(imdc)2] n  by using hydrothermal methods. Eu(III) and Ag(I) in 1 are bridged by 4,5-imidazoledicarboxylate and arranged in an alternating fashion to construct a cubical-like architecture. The solid-state photoluminescent properties of 1 indicate that the new compound 1 may be a candidate for potential photoactive materials.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Supplementary data</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">CCDC 681076 contains the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via <ce:inter-ref xlink:href="http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif" xlink:type="simple">www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif</ce:inter-ref>. Supplementary data associated with this article can be found, in the online version, at <ce:inter-ref xlink:href="doi:10.1016/j.inoche.2008.06.009" xlink:type="simple">doi:10.1016/j.inoche.2008.06.009</ce:inter-ref>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Supplementary data

CCDC 681076 contains the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif. Supplementary data associated with this article can be found, in the online version, at doi:10.1016/j.inoche.2008.06.009.

</ce:para><ce:simple-para view="all">Diffraction intensities for complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were collected at 293<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K on a computer-controlled Bruker SMART 1000 CCD diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>Kα radiation with a radiation wavelength of 0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å by using the X-scan technique. Crystal dimensions for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>: Monoclinic, space group <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>2/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>

<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.114<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−3</ce:sup>, <ce:italic>M</ce:italic>

<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>(Mo<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>Kα) 7.209<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>(0<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>0<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>0)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1064, GOF<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.058, <ce:italic>R</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.0187, <ce:italic>wR</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.0461 (<ce:italic>I</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>><ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2<ce:italic>σ</ce:italic>(<ce:italic>I</ce:italic>)).</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Supplementary data

   Crystal structure and report  Crystallographic data and cif/PLATON report.     

Diffraction intensities for complex 1 were collected at 293K on a computer-controlled Bruker SMART 1000 CCD diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromated MoKα radiation with a radiation wavelength of 0.71073Å by using the X-scan technique. Crystal dimensions for 1: Monoclinic, space group C2/c, a =10.751(2)Å, b =8.5706(17)Å, c =12.414(3)Å, β =90.30(3), V =1143.8(4)Å3, Z =4, ρ calc =1.114gcm-3, M =568.00, μ =(MoKα) 7.209mm-1, F(000)=1064, GOF=1.058, R 1 =0.0187, wR 2 =0.0461 (I >2σ(I)).

cln_elements.content: <ce:para view="all">All chemicals were of reagent grade quality obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. A mixture of Eu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (0.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 0.568<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g), Ag(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>) (0.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 0.0510<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g), 4,5-imidazoledicarboxylic acid (0.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 0.357<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g) and water (12<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) was stirred for 30<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min in air. Thereafter, the mixture was transferred to a 23<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL Teflon reactor and kept at 180<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 3 days under autogenous pressure. Cooling the reactor subsequently to room temperature at a rate of 10.8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C/h colorless crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were obtained. Finally, the colorless crystals were washed with deionized water and absolute ethanol (yield: 45% based on Eu). IR: 3441(w), 1554(s), 1508(s), 1465(s), 1383(s), 1244(m), 1100(m), 818(s), 782(s). Anal. Calcd. for C<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf> EuAg(%), C, 21.15; H, 0.71; N, 9.86. Found (%): C, 21.13; H, 0.71; N, 9.89.</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text: All chemicals were of reagent grade quality obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. A mixture of Eu2O3 (0.3mmol, 0.568g), Ag(NO3) (0.3mmol, 0.0510g), 4,5-imidazoledicarboxylic acid (0.3mmol, 0.357g) and water (12mL) was stirred for 30min in air. Thereafter, the mixture was transferred to a 23mL Teflon reactor and kept at 180°C for 3 days under autogenous pressure. Cooling the reactor subsequently to room temperature at a rate of 10.8°C/h colorless crystals of 1 were obtained. Finally, the colorless crystals were washed with deionized water and absolute ethanol (yield: 45% based on Eu). IR: 3441(w), 1554(s), 1508(s), 1465(s), 1383(s), 1244(m), 1100(m), 818(s), 782(s). Anal. Calcd. for C10H4N4O8 EuAg(%), C, 21.15; H, 0.71; N, 9.86. Found (%): C, 21.13; H, 0.71; N, 9.89.

cln_elements.clean_text:
Taking into account the excellent luminescent properties of Eu3+ ion, the luminescences of 1 was investigated at room temperature. Excitation of solid 1 at 394nm reveals that 1 displays intense red luminescence ( ) and exhibits the characteristic transition of a Eu3+ ion. The transitions are attributed to 5D0 → 7F J  (J =0, 1, 2, 3, 4) transition, i.e. the weak intensities of emission at 537nm and 653nm are respectively 5D0 → 7F0 and 5D0 → 7F3 transition. It is well know that 5D0 → 7F0 transition is strictly forbidden in a field of symmetry and, therefore, the Eu(III) in 1 should occupy sites with a low symmetry. These results are in excellent agreement with the crystal structure analysis. The 5D0 → 7F1 transition at 592nm and 5D0 → 7F4 transition at 702nm corresponds to a magnetic dipole transition both with medium-strong intensities. The most intensive emission in the luminescent spectra is the 5D0 → 7F2 transition at 612nm, which is the so-called hypersensitive transition responsible for the brilliant-red emission of this complex .

Supplementary data

   Crystal structure and report  Crystallographic data and cif/PLATON report.     

Diffraction intensities for complex 1 were collected at 293K on a computer-controlled Bruker SMART 1000 CCD diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromated MoKα radiation with a radiation wavelength of 0.71073Å by using the X-scan technique. Crystal dimensions for 1: Monoclinic, space group C2/c, a =10.751(2)Å, b =8.5706(17)Å, c =12.414(3)Å, β =90.30(3), V =1143.8(4)Å3, Z =4, ρ calc =1.114gcm-3, M =568.00, μ =(MoKα) 7.209mm-1, F(000)=1064, GOF=1.058, R 1 =0.0187, wR 2 =0.0461 (I >2σ(I)).

metadata.title: A novel 3D 4d–4f heterometallic coordination polymer: Synthesis, crystal structure and luminescence
